title: R42500
content: The legislative branch budget request of $4.512 billion, included in the President's budget, was submitted to Congress on February 13, 2012, representing a 4.8% increase over FY2012. House and Senate Appropriations Committees held hearings in February and March 2012. The House reported a bill providing nearly $3.333 billion for FY2013, a 1.0% decrease from FY2012. On June 8, 2012, the House passed H.R. 5882 with amendments reducing total funding by $3.113 million. The Senate Appropriations Committee marked up an amendment to H.R. 5882, providing $4.320 billion in new budget authority. The Continuing Appropriations Resolution, 2013 (H.J.Res. 117, P.L. 112-175) was enacted on September 28, 2012, funding the legislative branch at the FY2012 level with a 0.612% increase. Division G of the FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $4.307 billion in discretionary funding, $236.9 million below the FY2011 level. The legislative branch received $236.9 million less in FY2012 compared to FY2011. Previous funding levels were $4.543 billion in FY2011, $4.668 billion in FY2010, and $4.402 billion in FY2009. Additional funding was provided for specific agencies in various acts. Figure 1 shows the comparison of legislative branch discretionary budget authority with total discretionary budget authority since FY1976. The average annual proportion of total discretionary budget authority for the legislative branch is approximately 0.4%, with the highest level at 0.48% in FY1995 and the lowest at 0.31% in FY2009. The FY2013 U.S. Budget requested $4.512 billion in new budget authority for legislative branch activities, a 4.8% increase from FY2012. The legislative branch request is submitted to the President and included in the budget without change. The FY2013 discretionary appropriations were considered in the context of the Budget Control Act of 2011, which established spending limits for FY2012-FY2021. Due to the failure to enact deficit reduction legislation by January 15, 2012, automatic spending reductions were triggered, including sequestration and lower discretionary spending caps. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) was tasked with implementing across-the-board spending cuts to achieve equal budget reductions. The Budget Control Act of 2011 mandated spending cuts at the account and program level to achieve equal budget reductions from defense and nondefense funding. The American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 made changes to the procedures, delaying the sequester implementation and reducing the dollar amount of the cuts. The Budget Control Act of 2011 mandated spending cuts at the account and program level to achieve equal budget reductions from defense and nondefense funding. The American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 made changes to the procedures, delaying the sequester implementation and reducing the dollar amount of the cuts. President Obama ordered the joint committee sequester to be implemented on March 1, 2013, with reductions calculated on an annualized basis and apportioned throughout the fiscal year. The OMB estimated that P.L. 113-6 provides $4.277 billion in non-security FY2013 legislative branch budget authority and $8 million in security budget authority. The House legislative branch subcommittee met to mark up a bill that would have provided nearly $3.333 billion for FY2013. Issues raised included district office security and funding for the Architect of the Capitol dome project. The report will be updated with final FY2013 funding levels. The House legislative branch subcommittee met to mark up a bill that included amendments related to the Botanic Garden, House Inspector General audits, and online advertising funds. Two amendments were adopted, one increasing Botanic Garden funding and the other requiring audit reports to be provided to the House Appropriations Committee. The House Rules Committee considered various proposed amendments related to the Legislative Branch Appropriations bill, H.R. 5882. Members were required to submit their amendments by a deadline, and a total of 26 proposed amendments were submitted. The committee also reported a resolution for the consideration of H.R. 5882 along with another bill related to medical devices. The House Rules Committee considered amendments for the Legislative Branch Appropriations bill, H.R. 5882. H.Res. 679 was passed with a vote of 241-173. Seven amendments were made, with five adopted including funding reductions for the Botanic Garden and Congressional Research Service. Several amendments were considered for the Legislative Branch Appropriations bill, H.R. 5882. One of the amendments reduced funding for the Open World Leadership Center by $1,000,000. Another failed amendment aimed to prohibit the use of polystyrene products in food service facilities in the House of Representatives. A third amendment limited the number of copies of the U.S. Code printed for the House of Representatives to 50 copies. During the consideration of the Legislative Branch Appropriations bill, various amendments were proposed and voted on. One such failed amendment, H.Amdt. 1284, sought to prohibit funding for paid online advertisements by Members, committees, and leadership offices. Another motion to reduce funding for the Members' Representational Allowance also failed. The bill ultimately passed with a Senate Appropriations Committee reporting H.R. 5882 with amendments. The Senate requested $910.5 million for legislative branch accounts. The Senate requested $910.5 million for FY2013, an increase of 4.8% over the FY2012 level. The committee-reported version of H.R. 5882 would have provided $871.3 million. Appropriations for Senate committees are contained in two accounts, with $138.0 million requested for inquiries and investigations, an increase of 5.1% from FY2012. The Senate requested $425.6 million for FY2013, an increase of $29.4 million (7.4%) from the FY2012 level. The funds are allocated for the Senators' Official Personnel and Office Expense Account, which provides each Senator with funds to administer an office. The Senate requested $425.6 million for FY2013, an increase of $29.4 million (7.4%) from the FY2012 level. The Senate-reported bill would have provided $394.2 million, a decrease of $1.98 million (-0.5%). The FY2012 level represented a decrease of $13.0 million (-3.2%) from the FY2011 level. At a hearing on March 22, 2012, the Senate subcommittee discussed new responsibilities for the Secretary of the Senate and the Sergeant at Arms related to financial disclosure forms required under the STOCK Act. H.R. 5882 would have provided $1.226 billion for FY2013, the same level as requested for FY2013 and provided in FY2012. The House of Representatives requested the same funding level for FY2013 as in FY2012, with a decrease from previous years. A resolution in 2011 reduced authorized amounts for various offices and committees. Funding details for House committees are outlined in Table 6. The House committees, excluding the Appropriations Committee, were authorized $126.0 million for FY2012, a slight increase from the previous year. The Committee on Appropriations was allocated $26.7 million for FY2013, consistent with the previous year's funding levels. The Members' Representational Allowance (MRA) supports Members of the House. The House-passed bill for FY2013 would have provided $573.9 million for the Members' Representational Allowance (MRA), which is $39.1 million less than the previous year. Discussions in a March 27, 2012 hearing included topics such as district office security, legal expenses related to the Defense of Marriage Act, reduced budgets for Member offices, and implementation of the STOCK Act. The U.S. Capitol Police requested $373.8 million for FY2013, with the House-passed bill providing $360.1 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $333.1 million. The FY2012 funding level was $340.1 million. The USCP FY2013 request for salaries and general expenses is $373.8 million, with the House-passed bill providing $360.1 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $333.1 million. The salaries account includes funds for employee salaries, overtime pay, and benefits, while the general expenses account covers various operational expenses such as vehicles, equipment, training programs, and administrative support. Capitol Police requested $303.1 million for salaries, an increase of nearly $26 million from FY2012. The House-passed bill would have provided $297.1 million, while the Senate-reported bill would have continued funding at the FY2012 level. For general expenses, the Capitol Police requested $70.6 million, with the House-passed bill at $63.0 million and the Senate-reported bill at $56.0 million. Another appropriation for Capitol Police buildings and grounds was requested within the Architect of the Capitol account. The Capitol Police requested $30.8 million, an increase of $9.3 million from FY2012. The House-passed bill would have provided $20.9 million, while the Senate-reported bill would have provided $22.6 million. The FY2011 enacted level was nearly $27.0 million. Both bills included administrative provisions for fund transfers and depositing expired balances. Discussions at a hearing included costs for the Presidential Inauguration, overtime, and radio modernization. The Architect of the Capitol (AOC) oversees maintenance, operation, and development of the US Capitol Complex. This includes various buildings and grounds like the Capitol, House and Senate office buildings, Library of Congress, and Capitol Visitor Center. The AOC is also responsible for Capitol Police buildings and grounds, but not for Supreme Court expenses. The Architect of the Capitol oversees maintenance and development of the US Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. The Architect requested $668.2 million, an increase of $100.7 million from the previous year. The House-reported bill allocated $444.0 million, while the Senate-reported bill allocated $579.8 million. The Senate Appropriations Committee passed an amendment to provide $61.2 million for the restoration of the Capitol Dome, included in the AOC "Capitol Building" account. The House-passed level was $28.6 million, while the Senate-reported funding level was $91.2 million. The FY2012 level represented a decrease from FY2011 enacted level. In FY2010, a 21.7% increase was requested, and a 13.6% increase was provided. In FY2010, a 21.7% increase ($644.6 million) was requested, and a 13.6% increase ($601.6 million) was provided. In FY2009, a 55.4% increase ($642.7 million) was requested, and a 28% increase ($529.6 million) was provided. The FY2008 budget authority represented a decrease of 8.1% from the previous year. Discussions in a Senate subcommittee meeting included the Capitol Dome skirt project and the Capitol power plant. The House subcommittee discussed various projects and priorities, including the Dome skirt project, Capitol power plant capacity, financial management system consolidation, fire and life safety concerns, and Union Square improvements. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) requested a $44.6 million budget for FY2013, a $850,000 increase from FY2012. The House-passed bill proposed $44.3 million for CBO, an increase of $493,000. The House-passed bill proposed $44.3 million for the Congressional Budget Office (CBO), an increase of $493,000 (1.1%) from the previous year. The Senate-reported bill would have provided $44.6 million, the same as the requested amount. The CBO received $45.2 million for FY2010, with additional funding provided in previous years. CBO requested two administrative provisions for FY2013, including the use of voluntary student services. The House-passed bill included a provision for voluntary student services, while the Senate-reported bill did not. Discussions at the House hearing on February 7, 2012, covered zero-based budgeting, CBO's scorekeeping unit, dynamic scoring legislation, and biennial budgeting proposals. The Senate subcommittee meeting on March 15, 2012, focused on CBO's staffing plan and resources, including deferred IT purchases. The Library of Congress serves as both Congress's parliamentary library and the national library of the United States, with services including acquisition, maintenance, and preservation of a collection of over 147 million items. The Library of Congress provides services to Congress including legal research, law-related services, public policy research, and legislative assistance. The Library requested $603.6 million for FY2013, with the House-reported bill proposing $592.6 million. The Library of Congress requested $603.6 million for FY2013, with the House-reported bill proposing $592.6 million. The FY2012 funding level was $591.8 million, a decrease from previous years. The Library of Congress requested $603.6 million for FY2013, with the House-reported bill proposing $592.6 million. This represents an increase of $9.96 million (2.4%) from the FY2012 level of $413.7 million. The Senate-reported bill would have provided $415.9 million. The Copyright Office requested $19.2 million, an increase of $3.0 million (18.7%) from the FY2012 level. The FY2013 request for the Congressional Research Service was $109.2 million, an increase of $2.4 million (2.3%) from FY2012. The House-reported bill proposed $107.7 million, while the Senate-reported bill would have provided $107.3 million. H.Amdt. 1279 reduced funding by $878,000. The Library requested $51.5 million for Books for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, an increase of $848,000 from the previous year. The Architect's budget included funds for Library buildings and grounds, with proposed decreases in funding from both the House and Senate bills. The Senate-reported bill proposed a decrease in funding for Library buildings and grounds, while the FY2013 request included an increase. The Library also requested administrative provisions related to fund obligations and transfer authority. The National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped transitioned to serving persons with disabilities. Congressional hearings in 2012 covered budgeting, inflationary costs, Twitter archive, rental costs, oral history projects, copyright court project, and overseas operations, including the Cairo office during the "Arab Spring." Senate subcommittee discussed budget cuts in FY2011 and FY2012, buyouts in FY2012, and budget prioritization for FY2013. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) requested $526.2 million for FY2013, an increase of $14.9 million (2.9%) over the previous year. The House-passed bill proposed $519.8 million, while the Senate-reported bill suggested $513.8 million. The FY2012 budget represented a decrease from previous years. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) requested $526.2 million for FY2013, a decrease of $30.7 million from the previous year. The House-passed bill included provisions for fund transfers and discussed budgeting priorities. The Senate subcommittee discussed GAO's staffing requests, financial management system consolidation, zero-based budgeting, and TARP audit costs. The House-passed bill proposed $122.5 million, a decrease of $3.7 million (-3.0%). The Senate-reported bill proposed $126.2 million, the same as requested by GPO and FY2012 levels. This represents a decrease from previous years, with FY2011 at $135.1 million, FY2010 at $147.5 million, and FY2009 at $140.6 million. The FY2009 Omnibus Appropriations Act allocated $140.6 million to GPO, an increase of $15.9 million from FY2008. GPO's budget is divided into three accounts: congressional printing and binding, Office of Superintendent of Documents, and the revolving fund. The House-passed and Senate-reported bill proposed $83.6 million for congressional printing and binding, a decrease from previous years. For the Office of Superintendent of Documents, $34.7 million was proposed, a slight decrease from the previous year. The Senate-reported bill proposed $34.7 million for the Government Printing Office, a decrease of $272,000 (-0.8%) from FY2012. The revolving fund would receive $7.8 million, an increase of $7.3 million from the previous year. The congressional printing and binding account would see an increase to $4.1 million. The Office of Superintendent of Documents account funds the mailing of government documents for Members of Congress and federal agencies, as statutorily authorized; the compilation of catalogs and indexes of government publications; and the cataloging, indexing, and distribution of government publications, including the Congressional Record, Congressional Directory, U.S. Code, committee reports, hearings, and other documents. The House and Senate subcommittees discussed the Government Printing Office's budget request for FY2013, addressing topics such as Congressional Record distribution levels, the use of XML, diversity and training opportunities, and the future of printing in a digital era. The Office of Compliance, an independent agency, oversees enforcement within the legislative branch. The Office of Compliance oversees enforcement within the legislative branch, administering the Congressional Accountability Act enacted in 1995. The requested budget for FY2013 was $4.2 million, a 10.2% increase from the previous year. The House-passed bill included an administrative provision related to awards and settlements under the Act. The Senate did not include a provision related to awards and settlements under the Congressional Accountability Act in the Senate-reported bill. The Open World Leadership Center administers a program that supports democratic changes in other countries by inviting their leaders to observe democracy and free enterprise in the United States, initially authorized by Congress in 1999 to strengthen the relationship between Russia and the United States. The Open World Leadership Center, formerly known as the center for Russian Leadership Development, was renamed in 2003 to include more countries. Congress extended the program's eligibility to additional countries designated by the board of trustees. The center receives services from the Library through an inter-agency agreement. Funding for the center was reduced to $1.0 million in FY2013, with a directive to finalize program termination within a year. The Open World Leadership Center's funding has fluctuated over the years, with the FY2012 level being $1.38 million less than FY2011. Discussions have been held regarding the center's future and its inclusion in the legislative branch budget. Options for increasing private funding have been explored, including potential development hires. The House-passed FY2012 bill proposed a significant decrease in funding for the Open World Leadership Center, while the Senate-reported bill recommended a higher amount citing the program's importance for promoting democratic principles. The final Consolidated Appropriations Act allocated $10.0 million for the center. The FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act allocated $10.0 million for the Open World Leadership Center, with expectations for the program to become financially independent through private fundraising efforts. Ambassador John O'Keefe discussed the program's potential association with the executive branch during a hearing on the FY2009 budget. The Open World Leadership Center may attract different participants if associated with the executive branch rather than the Library of Congress. The FY2009 explanatory statement directed the Board of Trustees to establish a shared funding mechanism with the State Department and judiciary. Discussions on transferring the Center to the executive branch were held during the FY2008 appropriations cycle. In 2004, GAO issued a report on the program's participation, purpose, and accountability. The Stennis Center, created by Congress in 1988 to promote public service by congressional staff, did not receive funding in the House-passed bill for FY2012. The Senate-reported bill proposed $430,000 in funding, consistent with previous years. The Center's budget requests must include detailed justifications for future funding.
